citation.article-title: Actinomyces slackii sp. nov. from dental plaque of diary cattle

p.s: Description of Actinomyces slackii sp. nov.
Actinomyces slackii (slack 'i. i. L. adj. slackii named after J. M. Slack, an expert on actinomycosis and actinomyces)
Gram-positive, nonmotile, nonsporulating rods 0.8 μm long by 0.56 μm wide.
On horse blood agar after 3 to 5 days of incubation at 37°C colonies are white, smooth, shiny, translucent, and convex, have entire margins, and are up to 2 mm in diameter.
Grows aerobically or under 80% nitrogen-10% hydrogen-10% carbon dioxide.
Growth is stimulated by carbon dioxide in liquid media.
Acid end products are acetic and lactic acids, with traces of succinic acid.
The strains fail to hydrolyze esculin.
Acid is produced from raffinose, salicin, and glucose.
No acid is produced from L-arabinose , amygdalin, celobiose, inositol, D-mannitol, L-rhamnose, glycerol, sorbitol, melezitose, or D-xylose.
Reactions that vary among strains are shown in Table 2.
The cell wall peptidoglycan contains ornithine, lysine, glutamic acid, alanine, muramic acid, and glucosamine.
The cell wall carbohydrates consist of L-rhamnose and D-glucose, with variable amounts of galactose (Table 2) but no D-mannose or 6-deoxytalose.
The base composition of the DNA lies between 65 and 67 mol% guanine plus cytosine.
The type strain is strain Sh13/4563 (= NCTC 11923)
